title: Ticket #4260: condor_submit segfaults
description:
CMS would like to start testing the 8.1.x series, but cannot because condor_submit segfaults. Valgrind reveals: 

==21912== Invalid read of size 8
==21912==    at 0x4D82B78: find_macro_item(char const*, macro_set&) (in /data/srv/glidecondor/lib/libcondor_utils_8_1_4.so)
==21912==    by 0x4D82C0F: lookup_macro_exact(char const*, macro_set&, int) (in /data/srv/glidecondor/lib/libcondor_utils_8_1_4.so)
==21912==    by 0x4D82CCA: lookup_macro(char const*, char const*, macro_set&, int) (in /data/srv/glidecondor/lib/libcondor_utils_8_1_4.so)
==21912==    by 0x4D82F3B: expand_macro (in /data/srv/glidecondor/lib/libcondor_utils_8_1_4.so)
==21912==    by 0x411315: SetArguments() (in /data/srv/glidecondor/bin/condor_submit)
==21912==    by 0x41EF7E: queue(int) (in /data/srv/glidecondor/bin/condor_submit)
==21912==    by 0x420ED2: read_condor_file(_IO_FILE*) (in /data/srv/glidecondor/bin/condor_submit)
==21912==    by 0x4215F9: main (in /data/srv/glidecondor/bin/condor_submit)
==21912==  Address 0x732d8d0 is 0 bytes after a block of size 512 alloc'd
==21912==    at 0x4A07152: operator new[](unsigned long) (vg_replace_malloc.c:363)
==21912==    by 0x4D83F6E: insert (in /data/srv/glidecondor/lib/libcondor_utils_8_1_4.so)
==21912==    by 0x40D730: set_condor_param(char const*, char const*) (in /data/srv/glidecondor/bin/condor_submit)
==21912==    by 0x41F579: queue(int) (in /data/srv/glidecondor/bin/condor_submit)
==21912==    by 0x420ED2: read_condor_file(_IO_FILE*) (in /data/srv/glidecondor/bin/condor_submit)
==21912==    by 0x4215F9: main (in /data/srv/glidecondor/bin/condor_submit)

It appears when the macro table is re-allocated, we don't update the current allocation size. Thus, if we ever go over the default table size,

  • We reallocate the whole table each time we insert something.
  • We segfault if we insert more than twice the number of elements the table is initialized with (or more than 32 items if there is no default size).

So, the segfault can possibly trigger if there's ever more than 32 lines in a submit file. This makes sense above because each macro item is 16 bytes and the default size is 32, explaining the 512-byte allocation.

As a meta-grumpy-comment: there's nothing here that can't be done with std::vector and std::algorithm's sort and binary_search. Using the standard tools instead of rolling our own would have prevented this.
remarks: bug is fixed, version history needed.
